Award.AwardTitle: IUCRC Renewal Proposal: NSF I/UCRC for Friction Stir Processing
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal requests a five year renewal (phase II) of NSF funding for the Missouri University of Science and Technology (Missouri S&T) Center for Friction Stir Processing (CFSP) site. Missouri S&T was added as a university site in 2005.

CFSP is currently comprised of the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSM&T) as the lead institution, with Brigham Young University (BYU), the University of South Carolina (USC), Wichita State University (WSU), and Missouri S&T as research partners. These institutions were brought together to establish the Friction Stir Processing (FSP) I/UCRC to focus on the needs of the aerospace, aeronautic, energy, military and commercial industries in developing emerging solid-state metals joining and processing technology.

The CFSP has performed basic and applied research programs that address the implementation needs of its industrial and government sponsors. Missouri S&T focuses on the fundamental processing microstructure-properties relationships. Also, this site is the primary site for development of friction stir processing technology for non-joining applications. In addition to the success indicated by academic publications, notable commercial successes have resulted from the Missouri S&T site.

The broader impacts on the community are strongly built into the proposal through university, local, regional, national and international participation in the center activities. The renewing Missouri S&T CFSP site PI has worked as an organizer of FSW/P symposium during TMS meetings, edited the first book on FSW/P published by ASM, organized a Viewpoint Set in Scripta Materialia on the fundamentals of friction stir process as a Guest Editor and co-authored the first review paper on FSW/P. FSW/P symposium during TMS meeting is organized every two years and CFSP students participate in large numbers. All these activities help the broader goal of CFSP in generation and dissemination of fundamental and applied knowledge regarding the friction stir process. The renewing Missouri S&T CFSP Site has two post-docs in the research projects. During May 2010 IAB meeting, it was formalized that each site will develop and implement its own post-doc mentoring program. Missouri S&T site's mentoring program includes steps to develop post-doc's skills to transition into academia or research institutions.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for Friction Stir Processing (CFSP) was a multi-university I/UCRC. The CFSP focused on pre-competitive, fundamental research related to friction stir welding (FSW) and friction stir processing (FSP) technologies. In the second phase, the center consisted of three full sites, the University of North Texas, the University of South Carolina, Brigham Young University, and one affiliate site, Wichita State University. The CFSP had industrial sponsors from the United States, Japan, Germany, Sweden, and Brazil. Key, industry driven, thrust areas for the CFSP included the thermal management for FSP processes,microstructural modification for improved properties through the use of friction stir processing, improved process tool designs and operating parameters to obtain better properties in FSW of high-strength aluminum alloys, predictive modeling of FSW, and development of friction stir spot welding for automotive and aerospace applications. The overarching theme of center research was to improve fundamental process understanding thereby easing industrial application by reducing the need for Edisonian process development efforts.

As mandated by its Industrial Advisory Board, the CFSP focused on precompetitive fundamental research. Thus, the research was focused on using scientific principles to understand the operation and mechanisms underpinning friction stir based processes. Over the past decade, the CFSP has developed models that predict the effects of tool features on material flow, the effect of thermal cycles on the microstructure and properties of the weld and heat-affected zone, the effects of thermal control methods on the process, signal processing algorithms that can detect the formation of defects in real time, control algorithms that enable extremely tight control of process parameters, and methods for fabricating and testing complex spot-welded structures. The knowledge advanced during Phase II included these challenging aspects, (a) development of a physical metallurgy based super-predictor to minimize the process parameter search space for high strength aluminum alloys, (b) modeling of thermal gradient related property variation during FSW of thick plates of high strength aluminum alloys, (c) material flow and tool design for FSW of dissimilar metals and alloys, and (d) process design property optimization via thermal management.

The broader impacts of CFSP activities can be seen in a variety of outcomes and activities associated with the center. The UNT site has supported 11 PhD students in the Phase II of the Center. Many of these students have been hired into positions working directly on friction stir related technologies. Several have been hired by current or former CFSP sponsor companies. The UNT site was featured in the NBC-Learn's Science of Innovation series. In addition to dissemination of CFSP results through peer-reviewed journal publication, the PI published a text book on friction stir welding and processing; and started a short book series on friction stir welding and processing. The short book series has seven volumes from the center on topics developed during the life of CFSP. Overall,the Center personnel have striven to demonstrate the benefits of FSW/P to the broad engineering community and to make those benefits more accessible to potential users. The CFSP has been responsible for wide dissemination of a large body of knowledge related to friction stir welding and processing in the archival literature.


Last Modified: 03/30/2018
Modified by: Rajiv S Mishra
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Center for Friction Stir Processing (CFSP) was a multi-university I/UCRC. The CFSP focused on pre-competitive, fundamental research related to friction stir welding (FSW) and friction stir processing (FSP) technologies. In the second phase, the center consisted of three full sites, the University of North Texas, the University of South Carolina, Brigham Young University, and one affiliate site, Wichita State University. The CFSP had industrial sponsors from the United States, Japan, Germany, Sweden, and Brazil. Key, industry driven, thrust areas for the CFSP included the thermal management for FSP processes,microstructural modification for improved properties through the use of friction stir processing, improved process tool designs and operating parameters to obtain better properties in FSW of high-strength aluminum alloys, predictive modeling of FSW, and development of friction stir spot welding for automotive and aerospace applications. The overarching theme of center research was to improve fundamental process understanding thereby easing industrial application by reducing the need for Edisonian process development efforts. As mandated by its Industrial Advisory Board, the CFSP focused on precompetitive fundamental research. Thus, the research was focused on using scientific principles to understand the operation and mechanisms underpinning friction stir based processes. Over the past decade, the CFSP has developed models that predict the effects of tool features on material flow, the effect of thermal cycles on the microstructure and properties of the weld and heat-affected zone, the effects of thermal control methods on the process, signal processing algorithms that can detect the formation of defects in real time, control algorithms that enable extremely tight control of process parameters, and methods for fabricating and testing complex spot-welded structures. The knowledge advanced during Phase II included these challenging aspects, (a) development of a physical metallurgy based super-predictor to minimize the process parameter search space for high strength aluminum alloys, (b) modeling of thermal gradient related property variation during FSW of thick plates of high strength aluminum alloys, (c) material flow and tool design for FSW of dissimilar metals and alloys, and (d) process design property optimization via thermal management. The broader impacts of CFSP activities can be seen in a variety of outcomes and activities associated with the center. The UNT site has supported 11 PhD students in the Phase II of the Center. Many of these students have been hired into positions working directly on friction stir related technologies. Several have been hired by current or former CFSP sponsor companies. The UNT site was featured in the NBC-Learn's Science of Innovation series. In addition to dissemination of CFSP results through peer-reviewed journal publication, the PI published a text book on friction stir welding and processing; and started a short book series on friction stir welding and processing. The short book series has seven volumes from the center on topics developed during the life of CFSP. Overall,the Center personnel have striven to demonstrate the benefits of FSW/P to the broad engineering community and to make those benefits more accessible to potential users. The CFSP has been responsible for wide dissemination of a large body of knowledge related to friction stir welding and processing in the archival literature.
